messages.message:
Hey everyone, wanted to make a quick announcement about the work @Kai and I have been doing on redis deployments. We have *split our redis deployment into 2*, one persistent and one non-persistent, and have *deployed this to dogfood* and will be including it in the January release. Thanks @Kai for all the hard work to get this pushed out!

Persistent caching is currently being used for *ocr-msft* and *celery backend*. Everything else is using non-persistent caching. If there are any other use cases that need persistent caching, please reach out to us! Also please let us know if you notice any issues!

Awesome :smile: Finally!
In the persistent one, are we running it with fsync after each query? Trying to understand if we still have a data loss issue.
does anything need to change for how we run redis in our local deployments?

> are we running it with fsync after each query?
I think currently we are replying on OS to run fsync.
This is generally faster than syncing after every operation. Although this increases the probability of dataloss in case of restarts.

feel free to CMIIW @Aaron Tami @Kai
